Package org.interworldtransport.cladosG

package org.interworldtransport.cladosG
Provides the geometry classes and the structures needed for multi-algebra geometric models.

Background

Clifford Algebras are named after William Kingdon Clifford and were part of his attempt to represent geometry in an algebraic manner. The biquaternions are an example of such an algebra and are immediately useful as a space-time algebra. Clifford Algebras might have been in broader use in physics today in place of the Gibbs and Heaviside derived system if Clifford's proponents had better understood his work. Clifford died young in 1879.

In an applied sense, Clifford Algebras are a compact, efficient way of representing geometry in an encapsulated way. They capture many of the physical modeling needs for which we currently use vectors, matrices, exterior algebra, and some higher order tensors. There are many distinct algebras and a few different ways to encode geometric expectations with some looking familiar to the Gibbs/Heaviside system and others making better use of transformational symmetries.

While some make a distinction between Clifford and Geometric Algebras, that will not be done here. The clados library implements Clifford Algebras of at least one generator and leaves to the implementor how they choose to encode geometric expectations. However, the design of clados blocks many of the simpler modeling design errors a software engineer can make. Geometric operations that might be possible are also checked to see if they make sense.

The word 'Clados' is an acronym for CLifford Algebra Derived ObjectS. This acronym was chosen to avoid name collisions with other math libraries. A basic, complete geometric object is modeled by the Monad class, though most people familiar with subject will know them as 'Multivector.' The decision to use 'Monad' was based on a modeling need for objects that are aggregates of multivectors because 'Mult-multivector' is a mouthful. Monad aggregates, called Nyads, are modeled as lists. The names fit because lists of increasing size conform to the series {Monad, Dyad, Triad, Tetrad, etc.} However, for implementors not interested in these aggregates, the name 'Monad' is unfortunate. Treat it as a synonym for 'Multivector.'

Style

Clifford Algebra and Clifford Analysis are well developed subjects within Mathematics, but they are less so within Physics and Engineering. Clados is not an implementation for mathematicians. It it follows an applied style with extensions not necessarily related to Clifford Algebras. The author recognizes that Clados needs a fair amount of work to improve its mathematics pedigree, but is satisfied for now with a library that works.

  • Class
    Description
    Algebra
    The algebra object holds all geometric details that support the definition of a multivector over a division field {Cl(p,q) x ProtoN} except for the actual field.
    Basis
    All geometry objects within the cladosG package have elements that form a basis to span the vector space related to the algebra.
    Blade
    A Blade is essentially an outer product space built from 0 to many vectors.
    BladeDuet
    This class just acts as a bucket two blades when they are combined and reduced in product result discovery.
    CanonicalBasis
    This interface represents the 'contract' obeyed by a canonical basis in cladosG.
    CladosConstant
    This class just acts as a bucket for magic numbers so they aren't nightmarish to find when they change in the future.
    CliffordProduct
    This interface represents the 'contract' obeyed by a geometric product in cladosG.
    Foot
    Objects within the cladosG package have a number of attributes in common that relate to a point that describes where the geometry of the algebra is tangent to the manifold underneath it.
    GBuilder
    This builder gets basic information and constructs many Clados Geometry objects.
    GCache
    Any classes within CladosG that benefit from a supporting cache make use of this singleton enumeration as a 'builder'.
    Generator
    Generators are just place holders representing 'directions' in a space.
    GProduct
    This class defines a geometric product on an associated basis within a Clifford Algebra.
    Modal
    Anything implementing this interface has CladosF numbers that are expected to be descendents of ProtoN.
    Monad
    A CladosG Monad is better known as a multivector to anyone with experience with geometric algebras.
    Nyad
    Nyads are for all practical purposes just lists of monads that share a common Foot, but not necessarily common or unique algebras.
    Scale<D extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable>
    This class contains cladosF numbers that act together as the coefficients of a monad.
    Unitized
    Anything implementing this interface has "units" in the physical sense.
